message.content:
cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.MM, cs.SI, cs.DC 

Reasoning: 
1. cs.IT (Information Theory) - The paper proposes a novel idea of content adaptive MAC (CAMAC) to improve the reliability of wireless content delivery by aligning the modulation-and-coding (MAC) schemes to the content. This involves optimizing the transmission of information over wireless channels, which falls under the scope of information theory. 
2. cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture) - The paper discusses the use of caching popular content at the network edge to reduce latency in content delivery. This is a key aspect of network architecture and falls under the scope of networking and internet architecture. 
3. cs.MM (Multimedia) - The paper focuses on the delivery of multimedia content, especially videos, in next-generation mobile networks. This falls under the scope of multimedia research. 
4. cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) - The paper uses a stochastic-geometry model to quantify the gain CAMAC can bring to a content-delivery network. This involves analyzing the behavior of a network of nodes and falls under the scope of social and information networks. 
5. cs.DC (Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing) - The paper discusses the distribution of content helpers as a Poisson point process, which involves the use of distributed computing techniques. This falls under the scope of distributed, parallel, and cluster computing.
